title: How did Spain treat Native Americans, and how did they establish their relationship with each other? - Quora

response.answer_text: Spain treated the Indigenous peoples of the Americas with extreme violence, death, torture, mutilation, rape, and enslavement. The Spaniards used their superior weapons, guns,cannons, swords,cross bows, to crush any and all resistance by the Indigenous people. The power of the Church over the Indigenous was used to control them as well. Greed not God drove the Spanish Conquistadores and the priests. The Conquistadores were trained in rigorously in the use of weapons and warfare tactics. They also had the advantage of using horses in battle and using horses to cover long distances quickly. The treatment they subjected the Indigenous peoples of the Americas was that of a torturer over a victim. Inflicting the greatest amount of death to destroy their civilizations amounted to the genocide of millions of people. Out of all the conquests of the Indigenous people of North, South and Central Americas, there was only one group of Indigenous people, the Pueblo tribes in New Mexico, that successfully revolted and drove the Conquistadores and the Spanish priests and settlers out of their lands. Their relationship was that of the conqueror over the conquered. It was established by invasion, battle, total destruction and enslavement by the Conquistadores. The Indigenous people reacted by resistance to the conquest by the Spaniards. Their resistance resulted in millions of deaths at the hands of the Spaniards, including deaths caused by starvation and diseases brought to the New World. Power and control through physical force, and threats of violence was how the Conquistadores established and kept the relationship of master over slave between them. The Spanish Conquistadores of the 16th century Spain were professional soldiers who were trained in the use of weapons and mounted calvary. They explored, sought adventure, and riches in the name of King and Queen of Spain. Most of the Conquistadores were from Spain were Castilian although some were Portuguese, The expeditions in search of new land and riches was underwritten by the King and Queen of Spain, therefore anything they found, they claimed for the Castilian Spanish crown. In addition to the riches for the King and Queen of Spain, the expeditions were to bring Christianity (Catholicism) to any of the Natives of the lands that they encountered. The Catholic Church had enormous power and wealth during the 15th and 16th century’s, especially in Spain. Rome, back in the 12th century, had established Papal Inquisitions for the purpose of routing out heretics but more so, used on anyone that the Pope and Church felt were their enemies. They used it “In the Name of God the Father and Jesus Christ the Son” to amass power, gain control over political foes as well as friends, and to secure land and wealth for the Church.  By the 15th century, the throne in Castilian Spain established a “Spanish Inquisition” and issued decrees that demanded Jews and Muslims convert to Catholicism or leave Spain. The Inquisition was used by the throne and Church to ferret out “heretics” which most often turned out to be people who had “offended” the throne or Church, people who the throne or Church felt threatened by in someway or people whose land and riches were coveted by the throne or Church. The “discovery” of the New World, by a expedition paid for and authorized by the King and Queen of Spain, in 1492, caused a great stir throughout Europe. Spain envisioned exploring and finding vast lands full of riches, including the Fountain Of Youth. The Holy Roman Catholic Church in Spain saw this as a continued opportunity to gain more power and control for the Church in Spain as well as for the Pope in Rome. The Spanish Catholic Church, wanting to keep their coffers over flowing for themselves and Rome, urged the King and Queen to invest in sending more expeditions to the New World. The Church proposed to send along priests to minister to the expeditions and as a opportunity for them (Church) to bring many souls into the Church through baptism. The other “unspoken reason” was that it would give the Church the ability to insure it got its share of secured lands for the Holy Roman Catholic Church along with its “fair” share of the riches. It would also serve the purpose of keeping an eye out for any“political” matters that might be useful for additional power and wealth. Having the presence of the Church also meant that the Spanish Inquisition would/could be active when and if needed. Therefore, along with the Conquistadores went the priests, ready to claim souls for the Church along with claiming “other things”. The Spaniards had first invaded, conquered, and established colonies in “Hispaniola” (modern-day Dominican Republic and Haiti. Hernan Cortez, who had left Spain at 19 and settled in Hispaniola as a farmer and notary, spent seven years there. The treament of the Indigenous people by the Spanish was horrific. Many were killed, most had been tortured, raped, mutilated and then forced to work as slaves for the Spanish colonists. In 1511, Cortez heard of a new expedition, under the leadership of Diego Velasquez to conquer Cuba and joined it. While in Cuba, Cortez served in several official capacities and then was appointed as mayor of Santiago. The success that Cortez had in Cuba fueled his ambitions for more power, wealth and excitement. He convinced Velasquez to allow him to head up an expedition to invade and conquer Mexico. But when Velasquez called it off, Cortez took the ships, men and weapons and left anyway. Cortez and the Conquistadores that he led, landed on Mexican shores with an army of 500 men who carried superior European weaponry in 1519. They engaged in a battle with Indigenous people near the village of Tabasco, they quickly subdued the hostiles. Cortez went west and on then to the southwest coast of the Yucatan peninsula where he established Veracruz and claimed it in the name of King Charles of Spain. Here he spent time training his army and the additional Indigenous forces that joined with them into a great fighting force. He used discipline and training on his men to insure they were a cohesive force, he even burned up his ships so no one could leave. He and his forces marched on to the Aztec capital of Tenochtitlán in 1519. When the Conquistadores arrived at Tenochtitlan, the Aztecs at first thought Cortez a God. His fair skin and fair hair and eyes set him apart. They arrived on horseback, horses were something that the Aztecs had never seen before and they thought them to monsters with two heads and six legs. They were wearing shiny armor and carrying their superior weapons of rifles, swords, axes, and cannons. The Spanish fired off the guns and cannons which totally scared and intimidated the Aztecs. While the Spanish forces were treated well by Montezuma, the leader and ruler of the Aztecs, the Spanish made it clear they intended to conquer the Aztecs and take control over the city and its wealth. The Spanish sacked the city and took Montezuma hostage. Cortez ruled the city and people by using Montezuma to do his bidding. Later, the Aztecs saw Montezuma as Cortez’s puppet ruler.  Cortez formed an alliance with several of the tribes who were tradional enemies of the Aztecs. They joined forced and under Cortez, they learned the Spanish fighting techniques and in turn, taught the Spanish there fighting techniques. Meanwhile, Velasquez, angry over Cortez’s treachery, sent forces to Mexico to unseat Cortez. When Cortez got wind of this he took a garrison of his men along with the forces of his tribal allies and went out to meet the forces sent by Velasquez. Cortez and his army defeated the Spanish force and then returned to Tenochtitlan, where he found the Aztecs in full rebellion. He took his men and retreated but one of his men was killed and his body left there, which was how the Aztecs contracted small pox. Having no immunity to small pox, the disease ravished the population of the Aztec people living in Tenochtitlan. Over three million Aztecs died as a result of the small pox, and by the time Cortez regrouped and re-entered the city, the population was starving, dying of small pox and they put up little resistance,. Cortez rebuilt the city which had been reduced to ruins by the battles, into a magnificent city where many Spaniards and other Europeans came to settle, Mexico City. Cortez was rewarded by King Charles I of Spain with the governorship of Mexico. Cortez’s invasion and conquest of Mexico , caused the deaths of tens of thousands of the Indigenous people. He enslaved much of the native population, and many of the indigenous people were wiped out from European diseases such as smallpox. “Both scenarios would unfortunately become a common theme among many explorers' interactions with natives." Mexico was named “New Spain” and became a possession or colony of Spain, the King and the Holy Roman Catholic Church. In 1540, Vázquez de Coronado, who was the Governor of the providence of Nuevo Galicia, an area in Northwestern Mexico or New Spain, took a large force of Conquistadores, indigenous soldiers, slaves, four Franciscan priests and set out to explore the area North of New Spain. They had heard the stories of the survivors of two previous expeditions, of a large city, as large as Mexico City, high up on a mountain that was built of gold, they called Cibola They had heard stories of “seven cities of Gold or Cibola” as well as fertile expanses of land with large rivers running through. Coronado led his expedition up through New Spain and then into what is now California before cutting over to the east. He eventually arrived at the Pueblo of Zuni, where they were refused entry. They attacked with their superior weapons and trained soldiers and gained entrance. There they re-stocked their supplies by cleaning out the Zuni’s food. From there they went to Hopi, but found no gold there. Again they used force to gain entrance of the village, killing and maiming, and they took the Hopi’s supplies as well. They did winter by the Rio Grande at a village located along the shores. Once again they had to fight the inhabitants, it was a very fierce battle killing hundreds of the Indigenous village people.  Coranado spent time exploring up as far North as Kansas and eventually returned to New Spain (Mexico). 40 years later the Conquistadores returned to the area now called New Mexico. The Chamuscado and Rodríguez Expedition was led by Friar Rodríguez and a Spaniard named Chamuscado. It was a small expedition made up of some Spanish soldiers, a four priests, Indigenous slaves and black slaves along with some of the Indigenous people who had been “civilized” by the friars. They went looking for a village of people who were “advanced enough” to grow cotton and weave cloth to the north of New Spain (Mexico). They spent more time investigating the Pueblos and were impressed by how prosperous they were. They had bountiful crops of food, enjoyed fish from near by rivers as well as buffalo, deer, elk. They were very impressed by how large the pueblo village’s of two and three story homes built up on mesas.  Eventually, one of the priests wanted to return to New Spain and left. He was killed by some of Indigenous tribes along the way. Later, most of the expedition decided to return to New Spain to report on what they had found. Two of the priests refused to leave and stayed, but were murdered by the Indigenous people a few weeks later. The rest of the party returned to New Spain stirring interest in the colonization of the Southwest, New Mexico,Texas, Arizona and Colorado. In 1598, Juan Oñate led 500 Spanish settlers and soldiers with over 700 head of live stock to what is now called New Mexico. As governor of New Mexico, Oñate expected the total subjugation of the Indigenous people even though he commented on the similarities of the Pueblo people to the Spaniards themselves. Juan Oñate might have not expected much trouble in subduing the Pueblos because of the realative ease with which the Aztecs were conquered. However, it became obvious that the Pueblos were not going to submit so easy. Oñate later observed and experienced that they were to goingto be tamed like docile sheep. Instead, the Spanish had a revolt by one of the Pueblos, Acoma, that the Spanish brutally quelled. “The Native Americans at Acoma revolted against this Spanish encroachment but faced severe suppression. In battles with the Acomas, Oñate lost 11 soldiers and two servants, killed hundreds of Indians, and punished every man over 25 years of age by the amputation of their left foot. The Franciscans found the pueblo people increasingly unwilling to consent to baptism by newcomers who continued to demand food, clothing and labor. Acoma is also known as the oldest continually inhabited city in the United States."(Nash, Gary B. Red, White and Black: The Peoples of Early North America Los Angeles 2015. Chapter 1, pg. 5 ) Unlike New Spain, the Spaniards never were able to totally dominate the Pueblo people. “Missionaries attempted to convert the natives to Christianity, but had little success.” Contemporary scholars believe that the objective of Spanish rule of New Mexico (and all other northern lands) was the full exploitation of the native population and resources. As Frank McNitt wrote : "Governors were a greedy and rapacious lot whose single-minded interest was to wring as much personal wealth from the province as their terms allowed. They exploited Indian labor for transport, sold Indian slaves in New Spain, and sold Indian products...and other goods manufactured by Indian slave labor."[14] Wikipedia The Great Pueblo Revolt of 1680 : The Pueblo Revolt killed 400 Spanish and drove the remaining 2,000 settlers out of the province.  The various Pueblo tribes/villages, from the Hopi’s in Arizona, to the Zuni’s and Acomas, in SW New Mexico, along with the Pueblos along the Rio Grande, joined with the Northern Pueblos up to Taos, over a period of three years, led by medicine man named PoPay, years, they plotted to revolt against their cruel and inhumane rule and religion. Finally, on August 13, 1680, they rebelled in mass against the Spaniards and the priests. They were successful in driving the Spaniards completely out of New Mexico for the next 12 years. It was the only time in history that a Indigenous people were able to throw out the European Invaders.  When the Spanish years later. They negotiated a surrender of Santa Fe, where the Governor’s Palace was located and a peace agreement with all of the Pueblos. The Spanish continued to attacked by the nomadic tribes, the Apache and Navajo, but the Pueblos would provide fighters to help the Spaniards because they too face attacks by the two tribes. To this day, many of the Pueblo people have managed to keep their tradional beliefs,ceremonies and UCB of their culture alive because they managed to practice both their religion and the Catholic religion, by intertwining them, without losing their traditional beliefs. Note: Much of what I related here is history that I was taught orally, and later, in school by book. I was born and raised in New Mexico on a Pulebo Indian Reservation. My Pueblo great grandmother, and great great Aunts all told us children the stories that had been passed on for generations. I also was given the Spanish version of the history from my great grandmother, who had blonde hair, blue eyes and spoke pure Castilian Spanish. Her great- great -grandparents were part of the original Spanish settlers. I also used resources from Wikipedia and a very rare old book, “ New Mexico : Land of The Delight Makers” by George Wharton James, copyright 1920  This is a older photo of the Village of Laguna,where I was born and raised  This photo is one often seen in books on Pueblo Indians. They are a man and his wife, he is a leader of Laguna and is supposedly related to me.
